qas.question: What are some flying animals that Darwin thought might have evolved from bats?
What example did Darwin give of eyes evolving?

answers.text: simple eyes found in invertebrates, starting with nothing more than an optic nerve coated with pigment

qas.question: How did Darwin justify his theory not breaking down?

answers.text: any complex organ existed, which could not possibly have been formed by numerous, successive, slight modifications, my theory would absolutely break down.

context: His answer was that in many cases animals exist with intermediate structures that are functional. He presented <a0_0>flying squirrels, and flying lemurs<a0_0/> as examples of how bats might have evolved from non-flying ancestors. He discussed various <a1_0>simple eyes found in invertebrates, starting with nothing more than an optic nerve coated with pigment<a1_0/>, as examples of how the vertebrate eye could have evolved. Darwin concludes: "If it could be demonstrated that <a2_0>any complex organ existed, which could not possibly have been formed by numerous, successive, slight modifications, my theory would absolutely break down.<a2_0/> But I can find out no such case."
